OK, so we've seen how to compute
the first principal component.

And the description was that it
provides a summary of the data.
It's got the most variance.
Well, you can go further.

If you've got p
variables, you can now

ask for a second
principal component,
which also has large variance.

But unless you want to get
the same one as the first,

you have to put
some constraints.

So the constraint, the
natural constraint,

is that this second variable
be uncorrelated with the first.

So it's going to tell
you different information
about the data.

And subject to
being uncorrelated,

it's going to have large
variance-- largest variance.

So that's a problem
which we can phrase
in pretty much the same way.

It's going to be a
linear combination.

We've got it now indexed
by 2 instead of 1.
There's a sub 2 there.

And subject to that constraint
of being uncorrelated,

we want it to
maximize the variance.

Now, there's some interesting
math that comes with this.

It turns out that
being uncorrelated also
means that the alphas--

the phi's, I beg
your pardon, that

define the principal
component as vectors,
those are the loading vectors.

So the phi's for
the second component

defines a vector that's
orthogonal to the phi's
for the first component.

So that's just a
property of the solution.

And so we can characterize
that lack of correlation
as orthogonality of the phi's.

And the solution,
turns out, also

comes from the singular
value decomposition of X.

So the second
principal component

defined by the second
right singular vectors.

And there's going to be a third
component or fourth component,

and so on that sequentially
maximize variance subject

to being uncorrelated with
all the previous ones.

And it turns out that you
can have, at most, n minus 1
or p principal components.

So n is the number
of data points.

Sometimes p is bigger than
n, and if that's the case,

then we restrict it by n, but
otherwise, we just restrict it
by p, the number of variables.

So we get a complete
decomposition

of the data matrix in terms
of its principal components.

So as an illustration,
we're going

to show you an example using
some data on US arrests.

So for each of the 50
states in the United States,

we've got the number of arrests
per 100,000 residents for each
of three crimes--
assault, murder, and rape.

And we also have measured
the urban population,

the percentage of the
population in each state living
in urban areas.
So there's 50 observations.

So each of the
principal components

are going to be n vectors with
length 50 because they derive--
they're new variables.

And we'll get, at most,
4 principal components.

And each of them
will be described

in terms of loading vectors
of length p equals 4.

In this case, we actually
standardized the variables

before we did the
principal components

to have mean 0 and
standard deviation 1.

That's a fairly
standard practice.

And we'll get back
to that in a moment.

But let's first
look at the results.
So here's the results.

the first principal
component has

all three crimes.

And so this is a--

These are going to

see how they relate
